title: Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) | Description, History, & Facts
author: The Editors
description: Traditional Chinese medicine, system of medicine at least 23 centuries old that aims to prevent or heal disease by maintaining or restoring yinyang balance. Treatments include acupuncture, cupping, and moxibustion. Learn more about traditional Chinese medicine, including its history.

[National Center for Biotechnology Information - PubMed Central - Understanding Traditional Chinese Medicine Therapeutics: An Overview of the Basics and Clinical Applications](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8000828/) [National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health - Traditional Chinese Medicine: What You Need To Know](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/traditional-chinese-medicine-what-you-need-to-know) [Verywell Health - A Beginner's Guide to Traditional Chinese Medicine](https://www.verywellhealth.com/traditional-chinese-medicine-overview-5496352) [University of California, Berkeley - The Public Health Advocate - An Introduction to Traditional Chinese Medicine](https://pha.berkeley.edu/2017/02/01/an-introduction-to-traditional-chinese-medicine/) [Cleveland Clinic - What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?](https://health.clevelandclinic.org/chinese-medicine/) [WebMD - What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?](https://www.webmd.com/balance/guide/what-is-traditional-chinese-medicine#1) News [First randomized trial of traditional Chinese medicine for heart failure shows benefit](https://medicalxpress.com/news/2023-08-randomized-trial-traditional-chinese-medicine.html) traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), system of [medicine](https://www.britannica.com/science/medicine) at least 23 centuries old that aims to prevent or heal disease by maintaining or restoring [yinyang](https://www.britannica.com/topic/yinyang) balance. [China](https://www.britannica.com/art/china-ceramic-ware) has one of the world's oldest medical systems. [Acupuncture](https://www.britannica.com/science/acupuncture) and Chinese herbal remedies date back at least 2,200 years, although the earliest known written record of Chinese medicine is the Huangdi neijing (The Yellow Emperor's Inner Classic) from the 3rd century bce. That opus provided the theoretical concepts for TCM that remain the basis of its practice today. In essence, traditional Chinese healers seek to restore a [dynamic](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynamic) balance between two complementary forces, yin (passive) and yang (active), which pervade the [human body](https://www.britannica.com/science/human-body) as they do the universe as a whole. According to TCM, a person is healthy when harmony exists between these two forces; illness, on the other hand, results from a breakdown in the [equilibrium](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equilibrium) of yin and yang. A visit to a traditional Chinese [pharmacy](https://www.britannica.com/science/pharmacy) is like a visit to a small natural history museum. The hundreds of cabinet drawers, glass cases, and jars in a typical pharmacy hold an enormous variety of desiccated [plant](https://www.britannica.com/plant/plant) and [animal](https://www.britannica.com/animal/animal) material. In 1578 (Compendium of Materia Medica), which lists 1,892 [drugs](https://www.britannica.com/science/drug-chemical-agent) and some 11,000 formal prescriptions for specific ailments. The practice of traditional medicine To restore harmony, the Chinese healer may use any of a staggeringly large array of traditional remedies. The patient may be treated with [acupuncture](https://www.britannica.com/science/acupuncture) or [acupressure](https://www.britannica.com/science/acupressure), [moxibustion](https://www.britannica.com/science/moxa-treatment) (moxa treatment), or cupping (in which hot glass cups are placed on the patient to draw [blood](https://www.britannica.com/science/blood-biochemistry) to the [skin](https://www.britannica.com/science/human-skin)). The Chinese healer may prescribe a brew prepared with one (or some combination) of thousands of medicinal plants or dried animal parts (e.g., snakes, scorpions, insects, deer antlers) in the Chinese [pharmaceutical](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/pharmaceutical) armamentarium. The role of [qi](https://www.britannica.com/topic/qi-Chinese-philosophy) and meridians An essential aspect of TCM is an understanding of the body's [qi](https://www.britannica.com/topic/qi-Chinese-philosophy) (life force; literally, "vital breath"), which flows through invisible meridians (channels) of the body. This energy network connects [organs](https://www.britannica.com/science/organ-biology), [tissues](https://www.britannica.com/science/tissue), [veins](https://www.britannica.com/science/vein-blood-vessel), [nerves](https://www.britannica.com/science/neuron), [cells](https://www.britannica.com/science/cell-biology), [atoms](https://www.britannica.com/science/atom), and [consciousness](https://www.britannica.com/topic/consciousness) itself. Generally speaking, there are 12 major meridians, each of which connects to one of the 12 major organs in TCM theory. Meridians are also related to a variety of phenomena, including [circadian rhythms](https://www.britannica.com/science/circadian-rhythm), seasons, and planetary movements, to create additional invisible networks. In acupuncture thin needles are inserted into specific points along the meridians. The needles stimulate the meridians and readjust the flow of qi to balance the body's yin and yang. In place of needles, [massage](https://www.britannica.com/science/massage) (acupressure) can also be used to stimulate the acupuncture points. Acupuncture is sometimes accompanied by moxibustion, the burning of small cones of an herb (typically Artemisia moxa) at acupuncture points. Not only can the meridian network be used to [alleviate](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/alleviate) symptoms; it can also endow TCM with the ability to change [consciousness](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/consciousness) in those who receive [treatment](https://www.britannica.com/science/therapeutics). A TCM practitioner uses smell, hearing, voice vibration, touch, and pulse [diagnosis](https://www.britannica.com/science/diagnosis) to discover the source of an unbalanced [health](https://www.britannica.com/topic/health) condition, which organ it is related to, and which meridians are affected. In addition, the practitioner typically makes use of what is known as the five agents, or five phases ( [wuxing](https://www.britannica.com/topic/wuxing)). By observing [natural law](https://www.britannica.com/topic/natural-law) in action, ancient healers recognized five basic elements in the world—wood (mu), fire (huo), earth (tu), metal (jin), and water (shui)—and found that these elements have [myriad](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/myriad) correspondences, both visible and invisible. This framework helps skilled TCM practitioners to identify unbalanced relationships. For instance, one key correspondence relates to time of day. If an individual always gets a [headache](https://www.britannica.com/science/headache) at 4 pm, this signals that Bladder qi is unbalanced, since the Bladder (of the TCM Kidney/Bladder organ pair) is in charge of maintaining the body's functions at that time. Using the five-element theory, the practitioner can create a healing plan that might contain such components as acupuncture, herbs, lifestyle changes, and foods for healing. It might also include Chinese psychology, which shows how the energy of unbalanced emotions can affect proper organ function.
